bibl.title: espatch from Thomas Brown to W.H. Seward, March 4, 1867
Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.ab: Consulate of the United States of America Bathurst River Gambia 4th March 1867.
div1.p: Sir, Herewith I have the honor to transmit the return of the arrival and Departures of American Vessels and the statement of Fees for the half year ending the 31st December 1866.

The Fees, never a large item here, have considerably fallen off since the Rebellion of the Southern States in consequence of the bulk of the American Trade having since that period been carried on under the English Flag. For the last half year the total is only $20.23 a sum insufficient even to pay a Man to attend to the Flag+ Flag Staffsade.
By the return of Imports and Exports herewith enclosed you will see that the
div1.ab: To the Honorable W.N. Seward Secretary of State Washington
div1.p: trade between this port the United States has considerably increased tho with much

I have not yet received the for the 39th Congress and am therefore unacquainte with its provisions or into allorance if any been made as compensation for services at this consulate. The Office of the consulate is held at my own House which is rated at French Cuid of fifty dollars after and would readily let a Fifteen Hundred dollars I respectfully crave to be allowed Five Hundred and Fifty Dollarsa after for Rent of Offices.

I crave refernce to my better of the 20th November last renewing application for a New Seal and I now further make requistion for a large Flag to how at the Flag staff as also a small bon flag.
I have the honor to be Sir Your most obedient Servant Thomas Brown Commercial Agent
